Award.AwardTitle: Tracking Mobile Marine Species: Spatial Data, Visualization, and the Science-Policy Interface

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will examine how scientific studies that yield spatiotemporal data and visual representations of mobile species shape policy debates about control over highly migratory ocean resources and property. The project will provide new insights regarding the connections among the production, visualization, and interpretation of tracking data and their subsequent interpretation in science-policy relations. The interdisciplinary team of investigators will integrate the research areas of mobile marine resources and the control relations governing them to address questions dealing with resource control in the oceans. Project findings will provide new perspectives to resource managers and policy makers about the geographic range of transboundary marine resources and information to facilitate the development and implementation of meaningful conservation measures. Building on their extensive collective experience in advising governments, international, and regional and local organizations about the scientific and policy aspects of ocean management, the investigators will develop and disseminate study findings in academic and policy circles as well as to conservation and industry stakeholders engaged in marine resource management.

By studying the origins, products, and uses of tracking projects, this research project will link the relationship between science and policy to scholarship on resource control. The investigators will focus on four sets of core questions: (1) How do scientific representations of tagging data inform management debate and practice? (2) How have tagging data influenced the ways resource claims are made and assigned by and among nation-states, and how do interpretations of tagging data influence policy? (3) How do scientists determine the ways they visually represent their data to stakeholders? (4) How have policy and management needs influenced the research questions, species and study areas on which tagging studies are initiated? The investigators will analyze seminal studies, and they will employ an information cycle analysis, survey tools, meeting observations, and structured and semi-structured interviews to explore the intersections between representations of mobile marine resources and the policy-building processes to control or claim them at multiple governance levels. Data will be analyzed through transcription, coding, and the use of quantitative and qualitative survey and textual analysis software. Project findings will provide new perspectives regarding how science-policy relationships intersect with questions of resource-control decision making involving local, regional, and global stakeholders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to examine how new geospatial and temporal data about ocean spaces and resources has informed efforts to govern valuable ocean resources. This is important because the oceans are presently enrolled in a series of ecological crises and described as a valuable frontier ripe for novel conservation and extraction activities. However, oceans governance faces unique challenges because the mobile nature of ocean resources makes it difficult to define governance problems and to identify which entities have rights to exploit them or responsibility for their management. Novel scientific innovations that capture the spatio-temporal dynamics in the oceans promise to help fill these gaps by making mobile marine resources visible, and thus, more legible for management.

Our study focused on the specific cases of two highly migratory species with both conservation and economic value and that regularly migrate across multiple states’ jurisdictions and the high seas – sea turtles and Atlantic Bluefin tuna. We examined how satellite telemetry and other forms of geospatial data have enhanced understanding of these animals’ movements, and how this knowledge has shaped the trajectory of efforts to manage these species. This NSF award allowed us to analyze scientific data on high migratory species movements, interview key players involved in producing scientific data and in integrating scientific findings into policy frameworks, and to attend scientific and management meetings in which scientists and policy makers made decisions on how to act on these new forms on knowledge in management processes.

Our findings demonstrate that geospatial data has transformed understanding of these two species, and in turn, has revealed that management tools and political jurisdictions do not ‘accurately’ capture and manage the animals’ throughout their life cycles. As such, satellite tagging and geospatial data have contributed to driving political imperatives to reform and improve management structures to reflect the most current knowledge. Our findings showed, however, that while geospatial data reveals mismatches between the biological and ecological features of these animals and the tools and jurisdictions available for their management, the data alone cannot resolve these gaps. Instead, we found that acting on this new knowledge requires scientists and managers to address both scientific and social concerns, including: the durability of existing management structures in the face of scientific discovery; new dilemmas over resource ownership and the ‘right’ political and jurisdictional scales of management; the technical and political challenges associated with developing new – and more complex – scientific models to approximate the natural world; and new politics of science that increasingly collapses the science-policy divide. These findings advance knowledge in the fields of geography, political ecology and science studies by revealing the relationship between scientific discovery and the politics of resource management. These findings are also of interest to scientists in the field of biologging who are increasingly attentive to the importance of their work to policy processes.

These findings have been (and will be further) detailed in peer-reviewed publications. We have both organized and been invited to participate in national and international panels and seminar series devoted to the fields of oceans governance, environmental science, and data science. We have shared project aims and outcomes with practitioners throughout the project and will continue to do so as our findings are published.

This project has provided advanced research training and networking opportunities for three graduate students and one undergraduate student, and strengthened existing networks among researchers at University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, Duke University and the Monterey Bay Aquarium. Although this project has ended, further collaboration on the role of the emerging data science revolution in oceans governance is planned. Finally, team members have and will continue to integrate data science and oceans governance and our research findings into teaching modules at our institutions.
